strike out.translation[0].definitions[0]: to attack or criticize someone suddenly or violently
Unhappy young people will often strike out at the people closest to them.
strike out.translation[0].definitions[1]: to draw a line through something written on a piece of paper
strike out.translation[0].definitions[2]: to start walking or swimming in a particular direction, especially in a determined way
She struck out for the side of the pool.
strike out.translation[0].definitions[3]: to start doing something or living independently
strike out.translation[0].definitions[4]: to not hit the ball in baseball three times, so that you are not allowed to continue trying, or to make someone do this
He struck out the first batter he faced.
strike out.translation[0].definitions[5]: to not be successful at something
‘Did she say she’d go out with you?’ ‘No, I struck out.’
strike out.translation[0].definitions[6]: to say officially that something cannot be considered as proof in a court of law
strike out.translation[1].definitions[0]: to start doing something new, without other people’s help
He left the family business and struck out on his own.
